dict.string: Small bundle of descending axons connecting the cerebral cortex to the spinal cord. The tract is located in close proximity to the anterior median fissure and is not present below the thoracic region of the spinal cord. Unlike axons of the lateral corticospinal tract, axons within the anterior corticospinal tract do not cross over in the medulla, but descend on the ipsilateral side of the spinal cord until close to the region of synapse and then the axons cross to the contralateral side. Neurons within the cerebral cortex often project bilaterally within the anterior cortical spinal tract to synapse with neurons within the anterior horn of gray matter responsible for innervating axial muscles.

Also referred to as the ventral spinothalamic system, this spinal tract is responsible for carrying crude touch and firm pressure information from the periphery. The tract consists of axons from second order neurons from the contralateral side of the spinal cord. The axons within the tract ascend the spinal cord and synapse with third order neurons within the thalamus (VPL) and reticular formation.
Thin zone of white mater located dorsal to the ventral median fissure. Consists of nerve fibers crossing over to the contralateral side of the spinal cord.
Structural landmark on the spinal cord denoting the location in which the ventral rootlets exit the spinal cord.
The large bundle of dorsal and ventral nerve roots that continue within the vertebral canal below the termination of the spinal cord within the lumbar cistern.
Enlarged segment of the spinal cord usually spanning from the fifth cervical level to the first thoracic level. The cervical enlargement is involved with innervation of the upper extremities.

Rounded collection of interneurons on the medial surface of the posterior horn base between the T1-L3 spinal levels. Main function is as a relay nucleus for information to the cerebellum via the dorsal spinocerebellar tract, such as proprioception.
The termination of the spinal cord, which traditionally is located in the adult between vertebral levels L1-L2.
A strip of skin that is innervated by a single spinal nerve. C1 is the only spinal nerve without a dermatome.

Ascending tract responsible for convey fine touch, vibration and conscious proprioception from the periphery. The dorsal column of white matter inferior to T6 is organized into one group called the fasciculus gracilis. Superior to T6 the dorsal column is divided into the fasciculus gracilis (medially) and the fasciculus cuneatus (laterally). All first order sensory axons responsible for relaying fine touch, vibration and conscious proprioception at T6 and below enter the spinal cord and ascend within the fasciculus gracilis. All first order sensory axons responsible for relaying fine touch, vibration and conscious proprioception above T6 enter the spinal cord and ascend within the fasciculus cuneatus. Axons within each fasciculus ascend on the ipsilateral side of the spinal cord until reaching their respective nucleus within the caudal medulla. The axons of the second order neurons cross to the contralateral side of the brainstem within a group of axons called the medial lemniscus, which synapse with third order neurons within the thalamus.

This column of gray matter is formed mainly by interneurons, afferent projection nuclei, and central neuroglia. Sensory information from the periphery is relayed from the afferent nuclei in the dorsal root ganglia to synapse with the afferent nuclei within the dorsal gray horn. Two prominent parts of the dorsal horn of gray mater are the substantia gelatinosa and the body of the dorsal horn. This section of the spinal cord in the adult is derived from the embryological alar plates.
Longitudinal groove located in only the cervical and upper thoracic levels of the spinal cord. This denotes the separation of the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus.
Shallow narrow groove extending to the gray mater surrounding the central canal.
Collection of central axon processes from pseudounipolar neurons within the dorsal root ganglion carrying sensory information. Continues as the dorsal rootlets into the spinal cord.

Aggregation of pseudounipolar neurons situated within the dorsal roots. These are the cell bodies of the primary sensory neurons whose central processes pass into the spinal cord and peripheral processes travel through the spinal nerve. These pseudounipolar neurons are derived from neural crest cells. Satellite neuroglial cells are also present within the ganglion.
Continuation of the nerve cell processes from the dorsal root. The dorsal rootlets enter the spinal cord at the posterolateral sulcus.

Ascending tract responsible for conveying proprioceptive information from skeletal muscles and joints to the cerebellum. Axons relaying this sensory information synapse with Clarke’s nucleus. Axons from Clarke’s nucleus project to a portion of the lateral funiculus, which is the organized dorsal spinocerebellar tract. These axons enter the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle and terminate within the ipsilateral side of the cerebellum, thus no part of this tract crosses to the contralateral side. Clarke’s nucleus does not extend below the L3 spinal cord level, and thus neither does the dorsal spinocerebellar tract.

Rostral to T6 the dorsal column of spinal cord white matter is divided by the posterior intermediate septum into the fasciculus cuneatus and gracilis. Consist of the first order axons for the medial lemniscus system rostral to T6.

Caudal to T6 each dorsal column of spinal cord white matter consists of the undivided fasciculus gracilis. This fiber tract consists of large central processes of neuron cell bodies within dorsal root ganglia carrying information from various mechanoreceptors. Consist of the first order axons for the medial lemniscus system caudal to T6.

Collection of nerve fibers located within the white matter of the spinal cord on the border of the gray matter. These nerve fibers within this tract can be ascending, descending, crossed or uncrossed in interconnecting various spinal cord levels.

A long fibrous thread formed distal to the conus medullaris by the continuation of pia mater. The filum terminale continues inferiorly to attach to the coccyx, representing the original location of the developing spinal cord

Type of paralysis caused by lesion of lower motor neurons. The muscles supplied by the damaged lower motor neurons become limp and unable to contract. Reflex contractions are no longer attainable and the muscle will begin to atrophy.
Common division of the spinal cord white matter. Divided into ventral, dorsal and lateral funiculi.
Gamma motor neurons scattered within groups of alpha motor neurons. These motor neurons are responsible for innervating muscle spindles.

Column of preganglionic sympathetic neurons located between T1-L2. On the gross spinal cord this column of cells is evident as the lateral horn of gray matter. Axons of these neurons exit the spinal cord via the ventral roots.

Descending motor tract consisting of axons from the contralateral motor cortex (upper motor neurons). These fibers crossed within the caudal medulla at the pyramidal decussation to descend the remainder of the spinal cord on the contralateral side. Axons within this tract will synapse with neurons in the spinal cord along its length (lower motor neurons). The lower motor neurons leave the spinal cord to innervate skeletal muscle allowing for voluntary movement.

Together with the anterior spinothalamic tract, collectively referred to as the anterolateral system. Axons within the lateral spinothalamic tract convey pain and temperature sensation from the contralateral side of the body. The axons occupying the tract ascend to synapse with neurons within the thalamus as well as axons within reticular formation.

Located between the substantia gelatinosa and the surface of the spinal cord. Consists of centrally projecting axons from neurons within the dorsal root ganglion specifically relaying pain and temperature information. The axons within this tract ascend 1-2 spinal segments before synapsing with second-order neurons within the substantia gelatinosa.
Alpha motor neurons located within the ventral horn of gray matter responsible for innervating skeletal muscles.

Enlarged space between the termination of the spinal cord (L1-2) and the inferior extent of the arachnoid and dura mater (S2). Occupants within the space include: ventral and dorsal roots (cauda equina), filum terminale and cerebrospinal fluid.

Enlarged segment of the spinal cord usually spanning from the second lumbar level to the third sacral level. The lumbar (or lumbosacral) enlargement is involved with innervation of the lower extremities.
Located in the lateral portion of the ventral horn of gray matter between S1-3 spinal levels. Responsible for innervating sphincter and erectile musculature.

Motor neurons located in the medial aspect of the ventral horn of gray matter between spinal levels C3-5. The axons emerge from these neurons to form the phrenic nerve, responsible for innervation of the diaphragm.
Shallow longitudinal groove found at the posterolateral surface of the spinal. This groove denotes the entrance of dorsal rootlets into the spinal cord.

Descending motor tract consisting of axons from reticular formation neurons. The reticulospinal tract is made up of two smaller tracts: the medial (pontine) reticulospinal tract and the lateral (medullary) reticulospinal tract. This tract has many functions including: integration of information to aid in automatic movements of posture and locomotion, facilitates and inhibits voluntary movement and modulates pain impulses.

Descending motor tract consisting of axons from neurons located within the red nucleus. The descending axons cross immediately upon exiting the red nucleus to occupy the contralateral brainstem and thus spinal cord. This tract functions to provide strong output to limbs and allowing for accurate hand shape and placement (particularly in primates).

Column of preganglionic parasympathetic neurons located between S2-4. This column of cells does not form a distinct lateral horn of gray matter, though in a similar location as the intermediolateral cell column. Axons of these neurons exit the spinal cord via the ventral roots. Project to and synapse with postganglionic neurons for the bladder, bowel and genitals.
Common organization of both motor and sensory pathways in which particular portions of the body are represented in particular regions of a pathway or nucleus.

Type of paralysis caused by lesion of upper motor neurons. The muscles supplied by the damaged upper motor neurons present with hyperactive reflexes, are hypertonic and present with paralysis and/or weakness specifically in regards to fine voluntary movements.
Collection of motor neurons spanning from the caudal medulla to the C5 spinal level. The axons emerge from these neurons to form the rootlets of the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI).

Generally a mixed nerve formed by the combination of the ventral and dorsal roots. There are thirty-one pairs of spinal nerves. These nerves are responsible for carrying motor, sensory and autonomic fibers.

Distinctive region of gray matter capping the dorsal horn of gray matter. Primary, or first order neurons within the dorsal root ganglia involved in the spinothalamic tract synapse with the neurons located within this space.
Neurons whose cell bodies begin in the cerebral cortex, and whose axons descend through the spinal cord to synapse on lower motor neurons.

This column of gray matter consists predominately of a large aggregation of basophilic alpha motor neuron cell bodies, dendrites, axons and central neuroglia. This section of the spinal cord in the adult is derived from the embryological basal plates. Axons of neurons located within the ventral horn of gray matter grow out of the spinal cord and form the majority of the ventral root of spinal nerves.
A deep longitudinal groove that extends almost to the center of the cord.
The ventral roots are made up of axons from multipolar motor neurons located in the ventral horn of gray mater, as well as axons of preganglionic sympathetic neurons.
Collection of somatic and visceral efferent fibers exiting the spinal cord at the anterolateral sulcus.
